library(tidyverse)
library(ussf)
library(sf)
us_counties18sf_tn <- subset(boundaries(geography="county"),STATEFP %in% c("47"))

us_states18sf <- subset(boundaries(geography="state"), STATEFP %in% c("47"))

  geom_sf(data=us_counties18_easttn, fill="#ffffff", color="#262626", lwd=.5, show.legend=NA)+

  geom_sf(data=us_counties18_knoxco, fill="#FF8300", color="#262626", lwd=.5, show.legend=NA)+

## **Frameworks:** Spatial Theory

::: {.absolute top="0" left="100%"}
::: {.sectionhead}
1 [2 3 4 6]{style="opacity:0.25"}
:::
:::

<hr>

<br>[**Critical spatial theory**]{.green}[^1] calls for the interrogation of:

> "the intersections of space, power, and knowledge in order to expose geographies that perpetuate or disrupt inequities in both processes and outcomes" <br><br>(Annamma et al., 2010, p. 4) [^2]

[^1]: Soja, E. W. (2010). Seeking spatial justice. Minneapolis, MN: University of Minnesota Press.
[^2]:Annamma, S. A., Morrison, D., & Jackson, D. D. (2017). Searching for educational equity through critical spatial analysis. In D. Morrison, S. A. Annamma, & D. D. Jackson (Eds.), Critical race spatial analysis: Mapping to understand and address educational inequity (pp. 3-7). Stylus.

## **Frameworks:** Ecosystem Health

<hr>

::: {.absolute top="0" left="100%"}
::: {.sectionhead}
1 [2 3 4 6]{style="opacity:0.25"}
:::
:::

Like the butterfly and flora...

> "When youth are thriving, interested, and learning in a classroom, neighborhood, or informal learning program, we know the system is healthy. When they are struggling, we know the system is not healthy. Seeing learners as indicators could allow educational researchers to focus on youth as critical barometers of ecosystem health, while shifting energy away from creating interventions that target youth outcomes."<br><br>(Hecht & Crowley, 2020, p. 276) [^3]

[^3]: Hecht, M. & Crowley, K. (2020). Unpacking the learning ecosystems framework: Lessons from the adaptive management of biological ecosystems. Journal of the Learning Sciences, 29(2), 264-284. https://doi.org/10.1080/10508406.2019.1693381

## **Frameworks:** Opportunities to Learn

<hr>

::: {.absolute top="0" left="100%"}
::: {.sectionhead}
1 [2 3 4 5]{style="opacity:0.25"}
:::
:::

::: incremental

* What are the necessary conditions for learning?
  + [**Opportunities to Learn (OTL):**]{.green} "Affordances for changing participation and practice"  [(Greeno & Gresalfi, 2008, p. 172)]{.smaller-font}[^6]
  + Three conditions[^7]:
    - Availability
    - Accessibility
    - [Learner dispositions]{.fragment .semi-fade-out}

:::
  
[^6]: Greeno, J. G. & Gresalfi, M. S. (2008). Opportunities to learn in practice and identity. In P. A. Moss, D. C. Pullin, J. P. Gee, E. H. Haertel, & L. J. Young (Eds.), Assessment, equity, and opportunity to learn (pp. 170-199). Cambridge University Press. https://doi.org/10.1017/CBO9780511802157.009
[^7]: Norman, D. A. (1988). The psychology of everyday things. Basic Books.

## **Study 1:** Literature

<hr>

::: incremental

* In 2015 nearly half of rural U.S. secondary schools had no AP® program.[^9]
* Low-SES students are nearly twice as likely to attend a school with no AP® program.[^10]
* Advanced math is less available in small high schools, schools serving historically
marginalized groups, and rural high schools.[^8]

[^8]: Wolfe, R.L., Steiner, E. D., & Schweig, J. (2023). *Getting students to
(and through) advanced math.* RAND Corporation.
[^9]: Gagnon, D. J., & Mattingly, M. J. (2016). Advanced Placement and rural schools:
Access, success, and exploring alternatives. *Journal of Advanced Academics, 27* (4),
266-284.
[^10]: Theokas, C., & Saaris, R. (2013). *Finding America's missing AP and IB students.*
Education Trust.

:::

::: {.absolute top="0" left="100%"}
::: {.sectionhead}
[1]{style="opacity:0.25"} 2 [3 4 5]{style="opacity:0.25"}
:::
:::

## **Study 1:** Analytic Strategy [Aspatial]

<hr>

:::: incremental
* One logit for each AP® STEM course
[$$\frac{P_i}{1-P_i} = exp(\beta_{0} + \beta_{1}City_{i} + \beta_{2}Rural_{i} + \beta_{3}Town_{i} + \beta_{4}log(SES)_{i} + \\ \beta_{5}\sqrt{Enrollment}\;_{i} + \beta_{6}log(Prop\;Black)_{i} + \beta_{7}log(Prop\;Latinx)_{i} + \beta_{8}log(Prop\;Asian)_{i} + \alpha_{i}+\epsilon_{i})$$]{.much-smaller-font}
  + [$P_{i}$= Probability of offering course at school *i*]{.much-smaller-font}
  + [$City_{i},Rural_{i},Town_{i}$= **Locale indicator variables**]{.much-smaller-font}
  + [$SES_{i}$= Composite SES variable ranging from 0 - 999]{.much-smaller-font}
  + [$Enrollment_{i}$= Student school population]{.much-smaller-font}
  + [$Prop\;Black_{i},Prop\;Latinx_{i},Prop\;Asian_{i}$= Proportion of enrollment Black, Latinx, Asian]{.much-smaller-font}
  + [$\alpha_{i}$= state fixed-effects]{.much-smaller-font}

::::


::: {.absolute top="0" left="100%"}
::: {.sectionhead}
[1]{style="opacity:0.25"} 2 [3 4 5]{style="opacity:0.25"}
:::
:::

## **Study 1:** Exploratory Analysis [Spatial]

<hr>

[[**Spatial Autocorrelation**]{.purple} : Is the (in)availability of a specific AP® STEM course correlated with its nearby course (in)availability?]{.fragment}

[$$Moran's\;I = \frac{N}{\sum_i \sum_j w_{ij}} \frac{\sum_i \sum_j w_{ij}(X_i - \bar{X})(X_j - \bar{X})}{\sum_i (X_i - \bar{X})^2}$$]{.fragment}

<br>

::::{layout="[5,5]"}

:::{.center}

[**AP® Calculus AB**]{.green .fragment}<br>[$$I = .220 , p < .001$$]{.fragment .smaller-line-height}


:::

:::{.center}

[**AP® Computer Science A**]{.green .fragment}<br>[$$I = .262 , p < .001$$]{.fragment .smaller-line-height} 

:::

::::

::: {.absolute top="0" left="100%"}
::: {.sectionhead}
[1]{style="opacity:0.25"} 2 [3 4 5]{style="opacity:0.25"}

:::

## **Study 2:** Literature

<hr>

::: {.absolute top="0" left="100%"}
::: {.sectionhead}
[1 2]{style="opacity:0.25"} 3 [4 5]{style="opacity:0.25"}
:::
:::

::: incremental

* Multi-year sustained decrease in pass rates among Black, Latinx, and Native American students [^11]
* Low socioeconomic status (SES) students have a pass rate 17% lower than more affluent peers [^12]
* Men outperform women across all AP® STEM exams [^13]
* In 2015 rural students had the lowest AP® STEM pass rate of all locales [^14]

:::

[^11]: Judson, E., & Hobson, A. (2015). Growth and achievement trends of advanced placement (AP) exams in American high schools. *American Secondary Education, 43*(2), 59-76.
[^12]: Finn, C. E., Jr., & Scanlan, A. E. (2020). The roles of Advanced Placement in bridging excellence gaps. Fordham Institute.
[^13]: The College Board. (2014). *National report.*
[^14]: Mann, S., Sponsler, B., Welch, M., & Wyatt, J. (2017). *Advanced Placement across and success: How do rural schools stack up?* Education Commission of the States & CollegeBoard.
